I am a Berliner, Kennedy said, at the height of the Cold War.
The AP collection also offers footage of Marilyn Monroe's romance with Joe DiMaggio.
And there's even silent film.
Images show the aftermath of the 1906 San Francisco earthquake and the launch of the Titanic in 1912, much of this footage rarely seen.
The archives were generally quite inaccessible 15 years ago.
Which is why the AP's Alwyn Lindsey says the old footage has now been posted on YouTube.
I grew up in the 1970s.
I can look back and remind myself how I lived.
I can see the toys that I played with.
I can see the TV stars and film stars that I grew up with.
When he's done with the '70s, Lindsey can turn to the 1960s, one of his personal favorites.
Here's the story of the Beatles going to America.
(SOUNDBITE OF VIDEO)
UNIDENTIFIED MAN #2: Pandemonium paid a visit to the USA.
At that point in time, both America and the wider world was going through seismic change.
And whenever I watched that story, even though it's over 50 years old, you really do get a sense of how fresh and new and different the Beatles were.
Alwyn Lindsey on the AP's release of hundreds of thousands of clips of archival footage on YouTube.

I think we would be elated about how things were moving forward in this.
city.
We've been on the front end of all of the movements - the domestic partnership, the employee rights.
We've been a very strong community.
So this coming as it did was incredibly shocking.
And you know, not knowing exactly what went down, I - you know, I'm infuriated by it because it seems to be a break in our stride, you know (laughter)?
A break in our stride is a good way of putting it.
Yeah.
How big a break is it?

I don't know that it's a big enough break to register in any long-term way, but it's a tragic break in the sense that we are really concerned that this is the largest gun massacre in history or whatever we're hearing at this point.
And it happened two blocks from my house, and 50 people are dead.
I mean, it's very disturbing, and it's a lot of people.

And it's a lot of people who had hopes and dreams, a lot of people who might have been out for - I was looking at their ages - I mean, who might've been out for their first night at a gay bar, you know?
Because these were people who were 21 years old.
Right.
And it's pride month.
That's the part that hurts me the most.
I'm a 44-year-old man.
Seeing, you know, what I consider to be children have to face this is - it's very disconcerting.
And I want to do anything I can to help them.
Did you know anybody who was in Pulse?
No, I've finally figured out that everyone I knew was not in...
You say finally figured out.
Yeah.
It took a while.
It took a while - doesn't make it any better that a bunch of 20-year-olds are dead, though.
So I think - you know, I think our community is going to have a lot of healing to do at this point.
I'm sure there are people all over the country feeling like they want to do something.
They want to make a gesture.
They want to help in some way.
Is there something you would tell those people?
Well, what we've seen are thousands of people in line to give blood to save the lives of these people.
Yeah.
So I don't know that there's a charity set up yet.
I know that they're discouraging vigils right now because we're afraid that maybe somebody might come out and do something again.
How does that make you feel?
Terrified.
I mean, as a public figure, it makes me feel absolutely terrified.
And even being here and being on, you know, national networks and whatever, it puts me in the spotlight then, and then I am Whitney Houston in ""The Bodyguard,"" you know?
But...
(LAUGHTER)
Oh, my God.
I know.
I'm not trying to make light of it, but I mean, that's the first thought that came to my mind - yeah.
When's the last time you felt fear like that?
Have you ever felt that in your life before?
Yes.
I was shot by BB guns when I was a 20-something going to gay bars.
Out of homophobia?
Yeah.
Really.
The whole - I don't want to say the F-word, but yeah, it was said.
And I was shot from a truck.
They called you homophobic names and shot you...
Yes, yeah.
...With a BB gun.
Yes.
And now 20-some years later...
Right.
You're afraid again.
I'm afraid again - yeah.
I mean, the neighbor across the street from me has a Confederate flag on his truck, so I don't even know who people are anymore (laughter), frankly.
I mean, I just don't.
I mean, I just don't.
I mean, I - when I see something like what happened at Pulse - and we haven't gotten to the bottom of it yet.
But when I see something like that, I know that there is a nagging problem in our cultural being, our sociocultural being that needs to be addressed.
And I don't know how to address it.
I don't think anger is the way.
I think that we have to tell people about people's lives.
I mean, we'll do the hearts and minds things again.
Tell your own story.
